questions.text: What is the name of the incision shown below?
questions.solution:
• Option b) Gibson incision: incision made parallel to inguinal ligament used for ureter surgeries
  • Option a) maylard incision: transverse incision at lower abdominal wall
  • Option c) Robson incision: reverse Kehr incision used for bile duct surgeries
  • Option d) kocher incision: unilateral right subcostal incision used for open cholecystectomy, bilateral subcostal roof top incision known as chevron incision used for whipple's surgery for pancreatic cancer

Other incisions:

Mercedes Benz incision used for liver surgeries

Mark wood T shaped incision: used for spleen and pancreatic surgeries

Bevan incision: used for spleen and pancreatic surgeries

Incision used for appendix surgery: grid iron\mcburney incision, Lanz incision, battle incision

questions.text: A patient had a chest trauma, emergency open thoracotomy done, comes under which category of wound?
questions.solution:
• Option a) Clean wounds (class I) include those in which no infection is present; only skin microflora potentially contaminate the wound, and no hollow viscus that contains microbes is entered. Class I D wounds are similar except that a prosthetic device (e.g., mesh or valve) is inserted.
  • Option b) Clean/contaminated wounds (class II) include those in which a hollow viscus such as the respiratory, alimentary, or genitourinary tracts with indigenous bacterial flora is opened under controlled circumstances without significant spillage of contents
  • Option c) Contaminated wounds (class III) include open accidental wounds encountered early after injury, those with extensive introduction of bacteria into a normally sterile area of the body due to major breaks in sterile technique (e.g., open cardiac massage), gross spillage of viscus contents such as from the intestine, or incision through inflamed, albeit nonpurulent tissue.
  • Option d) Dirty wounds (class IV) include traumatic wounds in which a significant delay in treatment has occurred and in which necrotic tissue is present, those created in the presence of overt infection as evidenced by the presence of purulent material, and those created to access a perforated viscus accompanied by a high degree of contamination.

questions.text: Laparoscopic surgery was planned for a patient, patient developed bradycardia immediately after CO2 insufflation. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The physiologic effects of CO2 pneumoperitoneum can be divided into two areas:

  1. gas-specific effects and
  2. pressurespecific effects.

CO2 is rapidly absorbed across the peritoneal membrane into the circulation. In the circulation, CO2 creates a respiratory acidosis by the generation of carbonic acid. Body buffers, the largest reserve of which lies in bone, absorb CO2 (up to 120 L) and minimize the development of hypercarbia or respiratory acidosis during brief endoscopic procedures. Once the body buffers are saturated, respiratory acidosis develops rapidly, and the respiratory system assumes the burden of keeping up with the absorption of CO2 and its release from these buffers.

The most common arrhythmia created by laparoscopy is bradycardia. A rapid stretch of the peritoneal membrane often causes a vagovagal response with bradycardia and, occasionally, hypotension. The appropriate management of this event is desufflation of the abdomen, administration of vagolytic agents (e.g., atropine), and adequate volume replacement.

choices.text: ER, PR +, HER2- and K ras decreased
ER, PR +, HER2+ and K ras increased
ER, PR -, HER2- and K ras decreased
ER, PR -, HER2+ and K ras increased

questions.text: Luminal A Breast cancer is associated with
questions.solution:
• Luminal A - best prognosis
  • Basal type - associated with BRACA mutation, worst prognosis

questions.text: Mrs Gupta presented with carcinoma breast having liver metastasis. Which of the following is the best prognosis factor for the survival of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option a) age of the patient: increasing age is a risk factor. While the median age at presentation is around 60 years in the West (UK, USA), it is around 48 years in low-/middle-income nations such as India

Option b) nodal status of the patient: The pathologic status of the axillary lymph nodes is one of the most important prognostic factors in patients with breast cancer. Identification of metastatic tumor deposits in the axillary nodes indicates a poorer prognosis and often prompts a recommendation for more aggressive systemic and locoregional therapies

Option c) ER and PR status: tumors with ER and PR +ve status have good prognosis than ER, PR-ve

Non metastatic breast cancer: lymph node status

Metastatic breast cancer: ER and PR status

questions.text: A patient developed hyperthyroid crisis while planning for a surgery. Which of the following drug is not used?
questions.solution:
• This is an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. It occurs if a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy and is now extremely rare.
  • Very rarely, a thyrotoxic patient presents in a crisis and this may follow an unrelated operation.
  • Symptomatic and supportive treatment is for dehydration, hyperpyrexia and restlessness. This requires the administration of intravenous fluids, cooling the patient with ice packs, administration of oxygen, diuretics for cardiac failure, digoxin for uncontrolled atrial fibrillation, sedation and intravenous hydrocortisone.
  • Specific treatment is by carbimazole 10-20 mg 6-hourly, Lugol's iodine 10 drops 8-hourly by mouth or sodium iodide 1 g intravenously. Propranolol intravenously (1-2 mg) or orally (40 g 6-hourly) will block β-adrenergic effects.

questions.text: A patient presented with non reducible swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. X-ray of the patient is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above X-ray shows multiple air fluid levels indicating obstruction
  • The hernia appears below and lateral to the pubic tubercle and lies in the upper leg rather than in the lower abdomen.
  • Inadequate exposure of this area during routine examination leads to failure to detect the hernia. The hernia often rapidly becomes irreducible and loses any cough impulse owing to the tightness of the neck.
  • It may only be 1-2 cm in size and can easily be mistaken for a lymph node. As it increases in size, it is reflected superiorly and becomes difficult to distinguish from a medial direct hernia, which arises only a few centimetres above the femoral canal

questions.text: The fibres of internal oblique contribute to which component of inguinal canal?
questions.solution:
The inguinal canal is about 4 cm in length and is located just cephalad to the inguinal ligament. The canal extends between the internal (deep) inguinal and external (superficial) inguinal rings. The inguinal canal contains the spermatic cord in men and the round ligament of the uterus in women.

Structures contributing to the walls of inguinal canal

  • Roof: oblique fibres of internal oblique and transversus abdominis
  • Anterior wall: external oblique aponeurosis and internal oblique aponeurosis
  • Floor: inguinal ligament and lacunar ligament
  • Posterior wall: transversalis fascia and transversus abdominis

questions.text: On pentagastrin stimulation test-in which of the following condition acid is not increased
questions.solution:
Normal response by assessment of free and total acidity:

PENTAGASTRIN STIMULATION TEST

  • Fasting gastric juice is aspirated by ryle's tube → 'residual juice'
  • Gastric juice collected for next 1 hr is collected → 'basal secretion'
  • Gastric secretion is stimulated by giving 'pentagatrin'
  • Dose: 6mg/kg body weight
  • Gastric secretion is collected every 15min for next 1 hr

questions.text: Bile duct injury with injury of blood vessels in the hilum is given the classification name as
questions.solution:
• Strasberg classification is used for only bile duct injury based on ERCP.
  • Bismuth classification used for bile duct stricture based on MRCP.
  • Hannover classification used for bile duct with vessels injury.
  • Stewart way Classification used for laparoscopic bile Duct injury.

questions.text: Patient underwent cholecystectomy. The histopathology reveals carcinoma of gall bladder with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• Invasion of muscularis propria comes under T1b.

After laparoscopic cholecystectomy is done, the specimen is sent to pathologist for staging, treatment based on staging:

T1a involving mucosa only: no need further intervention

T1b involving muscularis layers → next step: check whether

  • Lymphovascular invasion present
  • Cystic duct margin is positive
  • Poorly differentiated tumour

If any one of these is present - extended cholecystectomy done (extra 2cm of liver resection)

  • T2 and above - radical cholecystectomy is done(4b and 5th segments of liver is removed)

choices.text: Size of stone >3cm in gall bladder

questions.text: The following are the risk factors of carcinoma gallbladder except
questions.solution:
• Several studies have demonstrated that the presence of a single gallbladder polyp larger than 10 mm carries an increased malignancy risk and cholecystectomy is generally recommended.
  • Gallbladder cancer is extremely variable by geographical region and racial-ethnic groups; the highest incidence is among Chileans, Native Americans and residents in parts of northern India, where it accounts for as much as 9% of all biliary tract disease.
  • Women appear to have a higher incidence across all geographical areas.
  • In western practice, gallbladder cancer accounts for less than 1% of new cancer diagnosis.
  • The disease usually presents in the 7th or 8th decade.
  • The aetiology is unclear but there is a suggested association with pre-existing gallstone disease, implying that chronic inflammation may play a role.
  • Calcification of the gallbladder wall, presumably due to chronic inflammation (porcelain gallbladder), is also associated with a small increased risk of cancer.
  • Chronic infection may promote the development of cancer and the risk in typhoid carriers is significantly increased over that of the general population.
  • Patients with PSC, especially with concomitant IBD, and those with an abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction are at greater risk of gallbladder cancer.
  • In patients with gallbladder polyps the risk of malignant transformation increases with increasing size of the polyp.

questions.text: The commonest oncogene involved in cancer pancreas
questions.solution:
• Pancreatic carcinogenesis probably involves multiple mutations that are inherited and acquired throughout aging.
  • The K-ras oncogene is currently thought to be the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer, with approximately 90% of tumors having a mutation.
  • This prevalent mutation is present in precursor lesions and is therefore thought to occur early and be essential to pancreatic cancer development. K-ras mutations can be detected in DNA from serum, stool, pancreatic juice, and tissue aspirates of patients with pancreatic cancer, suggesting that the presence of this mutation or others may provide the basis for diagnostic testing in select individuals.
  • The HER2/neu oncogene, homologous to the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFr), is overexpressed in pancreatic cancers. This receptor is involved in signal transduction pathways that lead to cellular proliferation.
  • Multiple tumor-suppressor genes are deleted and/or mutated in pancreatic cancer, including p53, p16, and DPC4 (Smad 4), and in a minority of cases, BRCA2. Most pancreatic cancers have three or more of the aforementioned mutations.

choices.text: Anomalous pancreatic bile duct junction seen

questions.text: False statement regarding the type 1 choledochal cyst is
questions.solution:
Choledochal cyst (CC) has been considered as a cystic dilation of the biliary tree at single or multiple segments of both the extrahepatic as well as intrahepatic bile ducts.

Patients may present at any age with jaundice, fever, abdominal pain and a right upper quadrant mass on examination; 60% of cases are diagnosed before the age of 10 years. Pancreatitis is not an infrequent presentation in adults. Patients with choledochal cysts have an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, with the risk varying directly with the age at diagnosis.

  • As it is DILATATION, drainage is not done. it requires resection.
  • It increases risk of cholangiocarcinoma and Associated with abnormal Biliopancreatic Junction.

questions.text: Bilateral adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice for which of the following?
Best diagnostic method for parathyroid adenoma is
questions.solution:
Preference investigations for parathyroid diseases in terms of reliablity (from best to least)

  • PET - CT - MOST RELIABLE
  • Sestamibi SPECT - better than Tc99m sestamibi scan
  • Tech 99m - Sestamibi scan- most commonly used
  • USG - LEAST RELIABLE

The sensitivity of sestamibi SPECT is 79% for Parathyroid adenoma.

The sensitivity of PET\CT is 93 % for Parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in this patient aged 25 years involving full circumference of right thigh, full circumference of both arms, chests and abdomen of front according to lund and browder chart
questions.solution:
Lund and browder chart

Full circumference of right thigh - 4%

Both arms full circumference - 2+2 = 4%

Front of chest and upper abdomen - 13%

Total - 21%

questions.text: Liver transplant in a recipient is contraindicated for which of the following tumor
questions.solution:
People with cancer who can donate liver for transplanataion are:

  • Non melanotic skin cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Brain tumours
  • Any cancer > 5yrs before

People who are recipient of liver for transplantation should not be suffering from any cancer

questions.text: Most common primary malignant tumor in children
questions.solution:
m\c primary malignant tumor in children is pilocytic astrocytoma

  • Pilocytic astrocytomas (WHO grade I) are distinguished from infiltrative astrocytomas by their more discrete borders, unique histopathologic and molecular characteristics, and relatively benign behavior.
  • They typically occur in children and young adults and are usually located in the cerebellum, but they may also appear in the region around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • The histologic separation of these tumors from other astrocytomas is supported by their relative circumscription, unique histopathologic features, and distinct genetic alterations of the MAP kinase pathway, the most common being a KIAA1549-BRAF gene fusion/duplication.
  • Pilocytic astrocytomas grow very slowly and can often be treated by resection alone. Symptomatic recurrence and incompletely resected lesions may be treated with repeat surgery, chemotherapy, or targeted therapies.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the nose?
questions.solution:
• BCC typically presents as a shiny, pink- or flesh-colored papule or nodule with surface telangiectasia. The tumor may enlarge and ulcerate, giving the borders a rolled or rodent ulcer
  • BCC is the most common periorbital epithelial malignancy, with a majority of these involving the medial canthus or lower eyelids. (tear area).
  • Area and rodent ulcer are key features here for diagnosis.

choices.text: High flow oxygen via nasal cannula

questions.text: A new born baby with scaphoid abdomen and breathlessness. Which of the following is not done?
questions.solution:
• A child with a scaphoid abdomen and breathlessness leads to diagnosis of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia. In this case bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated.
  • congenital d matic hernias are associated with lung hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, cardiac defects and gastroesophageal refux
  • CDH was considered a surgical emergency. It was approached using aggressive hyperventilatory strategies with the goal of obtaining pulmonary vasodilation through hyperoxia and respiratory alkalosis. This strategy often used high peak inspiratory pressures, ventilatory frequency, and oxygen concentration.
  • After birth, intubation, muscle relaxation and gentle ventilation aim to maintain pH, and oxygen saturation so avoiding right-to-left shunting.
  • Cardiac dysfunction, assessed by echocardiography, may respond to nitric oxide, prostaglandin E1, milrinone and inotropes, but severe dysfunction requires extracorporeal life support (ECLS).
  • Repair is offered if the pulmonary circulation stabilises. Unlike in traumatic diaphragmatic hernias, urgently reducing the bowel does not improve gas exchange in a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • The defect can be approached from the abdomen or the chest, either open or minimally invasively. The defect may be small, needing only a few sutures, or larger, needing a conical Silastic or GOR-TEX patch. A hernial sac may be present, which may be removed or plicated.
  • Bag-and-mask ventilation should be avoided because it may fill the displaced intrathoracic viscera with air and worsen respiratory compromise.
